fields.description:
We should add a text box and submit button to the bottom of every page, allowing end users to instantly submit feedback direct to an e-mail alias.

See the JIRA Studio beta for an example.
fields.summary: Instant feedback text box at bottom of each page
Clicking "Clear error from log" on a plan's page navigates to the Dashboard

fields.description: The Build Artifacts documentation talks about 'regular expressions' although the page talks about Ant copy patterns.  It'd be useful to have some complex examples.  I'm having trouble getting a complex artifact pattern to work, and some examples might help, since I don't really know what's happening.  It'd be great if you could actually have it show you what would match the results, but that's a nice-to-have.
fields.summary: Build Artifacts - Complex Patterns
Reshuffle the admin menu to have  Plan & Build Resources subheading

fields.description: The JDK and Builder pages have been removed for 2.0 beta. This is due to the underlying changes, however, they should be readded for 2.0 final
fields.summary: Readd Builder and JDK page

fields.description: You should be able to see which plans have the capability, which agents have the requirement and allow for editing of the capability keys
fields.summary: A capbility screen that allows bulk editing of capabilities and requirements

fields.description: When setting up an agent you sometimes want to test if a build will run successfully on that agent. It's often useful to force a given plan to build on a given agent.
fields.summary: Allow forcing a manual build on an agent
Readd validation of JDK and Builder for local agents
Two attempts to start a manual build of a plan in quick session locks the plan, and does not result in a build
getLastBuildResultSummaries is returning first, rather than last, BuildResultSummaries

fields.description:
Bamboo build hangs, if there is an issue with repository check-out on manual builds and stopping the build has no affect.

I first noticed this behaviour during blitzkrieg testing last week - and Mark just told me, the issue was also reported by Andreas in Bamboo 1.2x
fields.summary: Repository checkout tasks (CVS) should respond to stopping the build

fields.description:
Our CI build runs a maven2 goal as follows:

mvn clean clover:instrument clover:aggregate clover:clover clover:save-history 

Some of our unit tests are generating "errors" which we consider to be benign.  Yet, the build is still considered as failed and the Clover Results Collector is not run:

...
19-Jan-2008 12:30:55  Tests run: 283, Failures: 0, Errors: 147, Skipped: 0 
19-Jan-2008 12:30:55   
19-Jan-2008 12:30:56  [ERROR] There are test failures. 
...
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  [INFO] BUILD SUCCESSFUL 
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  [INFO] Total time: 138 minutes 18 seconds 
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  [INFO] Finished at: Sat Jan 19 12:33:46 PST 2008 
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  [INFO] Final Memory: 19M/​118M 
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ 
19-Jan-2008 12:33:46  Completed building build "SampleProduct - Trunk unit tests" return code = 0 
19-Jan-2008 12:34:40  Plugin 'Clover Results Collector' not run as build failed. 

The clover:clover mojo produces a valid clover.xml and the report shows 14% code coverage.   However, the Bamboo Clover plugin doesn't run since it detects the build as failed, and it reports 0% code coverage for the build.  There does not seem to be a maven surefire option to ignore test  "errors".

We'd like to see a Bamboo Clover plug-in feature or option that will allow us the ability to forcibly run the Clover Results Collector despite any test error(s) that would otherwise cause 0% to be reported.  This is because we want to 

Thanks for advice/suggestions on any possible workaround.
-Greg
fields.summary: Add option to forcibly run Clover coverage plugin even if build failed due to unit test error(s)

fields.description:
My company develops J2EE applications.  Our current application server of choice is WebLogic.  We are in the process of migrating from Weblogic 8 to Weblogic 10, and some of our apps have made the jump, while others have not.

Weblogic's J2EE implementation is part of the application server, not part of the application.  This means that it's not in our source respository as a JAR file, and it has to be included in the classpath at build time.   (Side note: there are actually about a dozen JARs that need to be included in this manner.)  Since we're using two different versions of Weblogic, each build plan needs to be able to specify which set of JARs to include.

Our old CI application (AntHill) provided us a way to specify a set of JARs to include for each build plan.  You drop JAR files in a directory on the build server, and Anthill creates a checkbox on the build configuration page for each JAR in that directory.  This solution is a little bit awkward.

In Bamboo, I have remedied this problem by creating multiple installations of Ant, and putting the Weblogic JAR files in Ant's lib directory.  Two installations of Ant for two versions of Weblogic.  Then I configure a builder for each installation, and name them "Ant 1.7 - WLS 8.1" and "Ant 1.7 - WLS 10.0".

This works, but it would be much nicer if I could define a library for each version of Weblogic, and specify a list of JAR files to be included in that library.  Ideally, I'd like a Bamboo admin to be able to upload JAR files via the web interface.  Then I could specify which libraries I want to include in the classpath when I set up the build plan.
fields.summary: Add ability to include external libraries in the classpath at build time

fields.description:
Scenarios - Your Bamboo 1.2x license has expired and you have just updated from Bamboo 1.2 to Bamboo 2.0 

Bamboo tells me that my license has expired - 
{quote}
Bamboo cannot be upgraded as your support period ended on 12 January 2008. Please come here to update your license if you have not already done so, and then restart Bamboo. 
{quote}
I click through and renew my  Bamboo 2.0 license,  i then redirected to the error.action page and told again about the error above. 

There is no confirmation that the license was actually updated.
fields.summary: Confusing to upgrade an expired Bamboo 1.2 license, to Bamboo 2.0!

fields.summary: Bamboo 1.2.4 import into Bamboo 2.0, throws exception due to UpgradeTask 612

fields.description: I imagine a similar problem exists if capabilites are edited to make a builder eligible.
fields.summary: Queued builds with no eligible builder are not built even if requirements are edited to make a builder eligible

fields.description:
Because we don't let users edit requirements, only delete and re-add them, it is easy to start unintended builds when editing requirements.

Consider the following scenario:

A plan exists with a custom requirement "agent.type" equals "local".  A user wants to change this to "agent.type" equals "remote".

To achieve this:

# The user deletes the existing requirement.
# At this point, the build becomes eligible to be built on agents with any (or no) "agent.type" capability, and such a build may start immediately.  This is not what the user intended.
# The user adds the new requirement.
fields.summary: When editing requirements, it is easy to accidentally start unintended builds

fields.description: I suggest that the "spinning" icon be replaced with a "warning" icon or similar.
fields.summary: Bamboo should indicate queued builds that cannot be built on any active agent

fields.description: Not sure why they aren't shown for normal builds that have a comments on them. This would be help a user quickly scan how all failed builds and whether they've been actioned by someone. (in Confluence we indicate this by commenting on the build)
fields.summary: Under the "All Plans" tab, bamboo only displays a comment icon for disabled builds

fields.description:
We currently have to allow anonymous access to our Bamboo server because of the following two bugs:

    http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-1930

    http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-1937

We have several people in our organization that leave the Bamboo browser application (Dashboard) pages up for days/weeks/months at a time.  However, we believe when their Bamboo client cookie becomes invalid the Dashboard still trys to get an update from the Bamboo server every 5 seconds. This results in thousands of attempts per hour against our Bamboo server.  A typical log entry looks like this:

INFO   | jvm 1    | 2008/01/16 14:51:51 | 2008-01-16 14:51:51,421 WARN [SocketListener0-46] [AuthorizationLoggerListener
] Authorization failed: org.acegisecurity.AccessDeniedException: Access is denied; authenticated principal: org.acegisec
urity.providers.anonymous.AnonymousAuthenticationToken@905571d8: Username: anonymousUser; Password: [PROTECTED]; Authent
icated: true; Details: org.acegisecurity.ui.WebAuthenticationDetails@0: RemoteIpAddress: 148.92.245.34; SessionId: 72mq8
0tj273mt; Granted Authorities: ROLE_ANONYMOUS; secure object: com.atlassian.bamboo.build.ViewBuild@83c7ce; configuration
 attributes: [WW_READ]
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2008/01/16 14:51:52 | 2008-01-16 14:51:51,953 INFO [SocketListener0-34] [AccessLogFilter] - http://b
amboo.palm.com/ 117781kb-1847kb 985ms
INFO   | jvm 1    | 2008/01/16 14:51:56 | 2008-01-16 14:51:56,671 WARN [SocketListener0-53] [AuthorizationLoggerListener
] Authorization failed: org.acegisecurity.AccessDeniedException: Access is denied; authenticated principal: org.acegisec
urity.providers.anonymous.AnonymousAuthenticationToken@905571d8: Username: anonymousUser; Password: [PROTECTED]; Authent
icated: true; Details: org.acegisecurity.ui.WebAuthenticationDetails@0: RemoteIpAddress: 148.92.245.34; SessionId: 72mq8
0tj273mt; Granted Authorities: ROLE_ANONYMOUS; secure object: com.atlassian.bamboo.build.ViewBuild@603950; configuration
 attributes: [WW_READ]

This drives our network utilization to 5 to 10% of a gigabit link and 50% or more of CPU on a Quad processor box.
fields.summary: Bamboo browser application (Dashboard) trys to connect to Bamboo server every 5 seconds

fields.description:
We should add a [Buildr|http://incubator.apache.org/buildr/] builder type. 

At the very least, we should add basic docs on getting it up as a Custom Builder.
fields.summary: Buildr Builder

fields.description:
This is due to autodetected JDKs on 1.2.4 having labels of the form "X.X.X_XX", whereas autodetected JDKs on 2.0 have labels of the form "JDK X.X.X_XX".

We should modify the importer and upgrader to add the "JDK " prefix when labels match the autodetected form.
fields.summary: JDKs autodetected on Bamboo 2.0 agents don't match builds requiring autodetected JDKs imported from Bamboo 1.2.4

fields.description: Unless the user takes some action that forces a rewrite of administration.xml, detected JDKs are never written to this file.
fields.summary: Detected JDKs may not be persisted

fields.description: Crowd has a special attribute 'requiresPasswordChange' which when set to 'true' can be used by integrated applications to initiate a change password workflow.
fields.summary: Implement the Crowd 'requiresPasswordChange' attribute upon login.

fields.description:
If there are no plans defined, every agent admin page states "This agent cannot execute any plans due to missing requirements".

This is misleading.  It should instead state, "This agent cannot execute any plans, as no plans are defined".

(While we're at it, I don't think the wording of "This agent cannot execute any plans due to missing requirements" is quite right.  How about, "This agent cannot execute any plans, as its capabilities don't match the requirements of any plan."?)
fields.summary: "This agent cannot execute any plans due to missing requirements" misleading when no plans defined

fields.summary: Bamboo does not work with Konqueror 3.5.7

fields.description:
In bamboo we organize our build plans in project according to the actual projects in our organisation.
Each developer in the project team should be allowed to view and build all plans with the project.

In order to realize this, we need to set permissions on every plan within the project definition, which can be up to 25 builds for some projects.
Having the ability to set the permission on project and have them propagated to all build plans in the project would make bamboo even a greater tool!
fields.summary: Add possibility to set permissions on a project.

fields.description:
The Windows and Mac installers for Bamboo automatically set the Bamboo home directory in the bamboo-init.properties file.

In the same way, they should set the JMS broker URI in the same file.

Without this, Bamboo users will be forced to manually edit the bamboo-init.properties file, even when using an automated installer.
fields.summary: Installers should configure JMS broker URI
Upgrade Task to convert allowed builds for queues to capability/requirements
Remote Agent installer screen

fields.description:
A CVS build plan has started being retriggered, after being triggered initially.  The first triggering shows up with a correct "Updated by" message.  The rest of them reports "Updated by unknown".

The offending project has a child build plan that is using a checkout of the same module, but on a branch.

(What the two projects together with a perforce project are doing, are to zip up eclipse plug-in projects and store the zip file in a local maven repository.  They are chained with dependencies, and the end of the chain unpacks the zip'ed up sources to do a headless PDE build of an eclipse RCP application.)
fields.summary: CVS build plan is being retriggered, reports "Updated by Unknown" after being retriggered

fields.description:
While creating a new plan on [BEAC|https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com] (2.0-SNAPSHOT), I got a warning:

bq. There is currently no Instant Messaging Server or Email Server Configured. Bamboo will not send out any notifications.

However, there _is_ both a mail server and IM server configured on this server. I tested the IM server and it's working correctly. The logic that displays this error message during build creation seems to be checking something incorrectly.
fields.summary: Incorrect warning about "mail server and IM server not configured" on BEAC

fields.description:
We should add documentation of the specific options contained in atlassian-user.xml to this page:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO012/5.13.2+Integrating+Bamboo+with+LDAP

A specific point that would have helped avoid a support case ([BSP-472|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-472]):  If the "securityAuthentication" option is set to "none", then the "securityPrincipal" and "securityCredential" options must be removed or commented out.
fields.summary: Documentation for the specific options in atlassian-user.xml

fields.description: The current version of Bamboo uses Jetty, but has a custom launch mechanism, which means that there is no easy way to use the AJPv13 connector that ships with Jetty.  It should be possible to include the ability to either use a different startup class to enable AJP, or a runtime/configuration flag.
fields.summary: AJP Support for Bamboo

fields.description:
h1. Explicitly stating whether a build contains tests is error prone and likely to produce modules that are untested

Currently, I am forced to explicitly configure whether a module will produce test results. This is higly error-prone as:
1) A given Maven profile might exlude running tests and if I have configured that tests will be run, the build fails although Maven repors successful build.
2) A given module without tests must be specified as such, causing tests that are added in the future not to be run by Bamboo.

I cannot see why this is something I must tell Bamboo explicitly. I defintetely think this is a bug, it should be possible to ignore missing test output and flag the build as successful, as well as flag the build as failed if there are test failures.
fields.summary: Automatically detect whether tests are run for a plan

From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257260434#257260434

{quote}Is there any way of getting metadata(Artifacts path for example) from triggering plan in a child plan ?{quote}

fields.description:
The upgrade of troy.sydney.atlassian.com Bamboo instance failed due to some of the buildresults xml files being null. 

Bamboo should validate XML files and the entire upgrade process should not die if one or more of the build result xml files are corrupted.

See attached logs for details.
fields.summary: Bamboo upgrade task fails if the build Results XML file is corrupted

fields.description:
Often, build artifacts are textual log files that can benefit a great deal from compression. 

At the moment, it is very inconvenient having to wait to download a 2M log file, which under compression would be less than ~100K. 

My suggestion is to provide a TGZ option next to each downloadable artifact. 

As a first cut, I'd be happy if _all_ the build artifacts were rolled into one zip - as this would already produce a bundle that is far smaller than one of the log files I download at the moment.
fields.summary: Provide option to download all build artifacts as a zipped file

fields.description:
The 'changes' command does not appear to working correctly for our instance of Bamboo 1.2.4 .

e.g.:

changes CCD-WCLV-300
cenqua-bamboo@chat.atlassian.com
14-Dec 4:54
Returning all commits comments for CCD-WCLV-331...

Change by Michael Studmann:
CLOV-121: Unborking WITH.CLOVER build.

http://troy.sydney.atlassian.com/bamboo/browse/CCD-WCLV-331/commit

CCD-WCLV-300 is not being respected.
fields.summary: 'changes' command not working via Jabber Interface

fields.description: When kicking off rebuilds of failed builds, it becomes an annoyance to have to go up to the main build each time in order to have the option to rebuild.
fields.summary: Provide the option to kick off a rebuild from a build result page

fields.description:
Currently, users can set system variables specific to their builds. However it is not possible to edit and pass down pre-existing system variables to Bamboo.

For example, PATH variable.

Requested by customer in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-460
fields.summary: Ability to modify system variables and pass them down to builds.

fields.description:
When our team has one Build Notification Trigger, where both Committer and an email address should be notified, this generates 2 emails.
We do this, to keep all team members notified about some special build results.
BUT... this is a P.I.T.A. when I do a commit - then I get 2 identical mail (one as committer and one as team member).

Combine this, so that one Build Notification Trigger sends one mail to all recipient. If "someone" needs to be on a secret mail-list, then create a new Notification Trigger.

Thanks for good product!

Peter Sone Koldkjær
End2End
fields.summary: Emails sent based on Build Notification

fields.description:
The BuildResultsImpl.cloneAsBuildResults() does not copy the data included in the customBuildData variable.  This causes a problem for the Cobertura and PMD plugins, as the BuildProcessor for each plugin stores the parsed data within the customBuildData of the buildResults, which ultimately means that the plugin results don't get displayed in the Bamboo UI.

The cloneAsBuildResults() method is used as part of the SaveBuildTask class.  Since the customBuildData is not getting stored, the CustomIndexReader instance does not retrieve the correct information.
fields.summary: BuildResultsImpl.cloneAsBuildResults() does not copy the data included in the customBuildData variable

fields.description:
Allow anonymous users and group confluence-users to export pages to PDF/Word.

Note: This is space permission 'Pages --> Export' only. (Not space export.)
fields.summary: Allow page-export on BAMBOO spaces for confluence-users and anonymous

Currently Bamboo only supports Perforce authentication by p4 password

Bamboo should also support [perforce ticket|http://www.perforce.com/perforce/doc.061/manuals/cmdref/tickets.html] authentication.

Coverage plugin causes Outofmemory exceptions when exporting data. 

This means, users shoul upgrade Bamboo versions by pointing to Bamboo-Home instead of exporting.

In some environments, an unknown third-party application is adding the line "-e" to the beginning of mailcap files.  JavaMail fails to parse these files and throws an NullPointerException.  See [BSP-442|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-442] for an example.

Bamboo should detect this problem, and make allowance for it.
fields.summary: Detection and handling of invalid mailcap file

fields.description:
This document needs to be checked/tweaked, then copied to the 1.2 space.

It will then need to be re-worked for the 2.0 launch.
fields.summary: review 'Logging in Bamboo'

fields.description: Currently Global variables in Bamboo are limited to alphanumeric characters. It would be useful if users can use underscores to name their global varaiables
fields.summary: Use underscores as names for global variables in Bamboo.

fields.description:
I think we should split up the [Specifying a Plan's Build Resources|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/2.1+Specifying+a+Plan%27s+Build+Resources] into child pages for each  builder in Bamboo. Similar to how we split up documentation on [Specifying Bamboo source repository|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/1.7+Specifying+a+Plan%27s+Source+Repository] into Perforce, CVS and SVN.

Also, the [NAnt builder|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMEXT/NAnt+Builder] now ships with Bamboo and at the very least we need to update the docs and give instructions on configuring NAnt builder
fields.summary: Improvements to "Specifying a Plan's Build Resources" page

fields.description:
This often results in Bamboo being started with an incompatible JRE (e.g. libgcj - see [BSP-447|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-447]).

To fix this, $JAVA_HOME/bin/ needs to be added to the beginning of RUN_CMD.
fields.summary: bamboo.sh assumes that the correct "java" executable is on the path

fields.description:
Right now, build notification email contains only one link to the latest build: e.g.  "Click http://buildserver:8085/browse/MED14-ABC-112 to find out more."

It'd be great to add links to the artifacts produced by the build.
fields.summary: Add artifacts section to build notification emails.

fields.description:
This connection method is used for Kerberos 5 authentication using GSSAPI.

Originally raised as [BSP-443|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-443].
fields.summary: Support for the CVS gserver connection method

fields.description:
1. Disable Anonymous in Global permissions
2. Create a plan with anonymous access disabled
3. Make a build with artifacts
4. Copy artifact URL to clipboard
5. Log out or open another browser window
6. Paste the URL into browser
Expected: login screen or Access Denied message
Actual: artifact is vieable and downloadable

Note: it seems that *download* servlet isn't secured anyway.
fields.summary: Anonymous user is able to download artifacts even if Anonymous mode is disabled both at global level and plan level

fields.description:
As seen in [BSP-439|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-439], if the text "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" appears in the last 100 lines of a build that ultimately fails and produces a "BUILD FAILED" message, Bamboo's Ant and Maven builder misinterpret this as a successful build.

To address this issue, these builders should also search for "BUILD FAILED" messages as well, and act on the last message found in the build log.

As a workaround, you can control the number of lines that Bamboo searches for a "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" message, by setting an environment variable named "SUCCESS_MESSAGE_LINES" before starting Bamboo.  You can disable this search completely, relying solely on the return code of your build, by setting this environment variable to 0.
fields.summary: "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" appearing shortly before a final "BUILD FAILED" message is misinterpreted as a successful build

fields.description:
Problems can occur when a Bamboo instance is run on an unsupported JRE (e.g [BSP-437|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-437]).

To ease diagnosis of this situation, Bamboo should, as part of its bootstrapping, check the JRE, and produce a prominent warning in the logs if it is not one of the JREs explicitly supported by Bamboo.
fields.summary: Include a prominent warning in the Bamboo log when running on an unsupported JRE

fields.description:
Bamboo has undocumented restrictions with how you can use global variable substitution for a plan's goal.  In our case, we have a batch of plans that all share the same set of verbose configuration options.

I defined a global variable, {{OPT.DBSETTINGS}} to represent a series of options that are common to several builds.  This looks something like:

{{-Ddb.host=our.db.server -Ddb.port=5001 -Ddb.dbname=xe}}

It's a fair bit longer than that, but you get the idea.  I passed this as a goal to our maven 1 builder like this:

*Goal:* {{${bamboo.OPT.DBSETTINGS} full}}

This doesn't get passed to maven in the way I'd hoped. Instead of:
||Property||Value||
|db.host|our.db.server|
|db.port|5001|
|db.dbname|xe|

..maven receives:
||Property||Value||
|db.host|our.db.server -Ddb.port=5001 -Ddb.dbname=xe|
|db.port|_not set_|
|db.dbname|_not set_|

Other global variables of the form {{-Dpropertyname=value}} get through as expected.
fields.summary: Variable substitution should not assume that the result will be contained within a single command argument

fields.description: The Maven2 builder in Bamboo should use the --batch-mode option on Maven's command line to instruct Maven that it is a non-interactive build.
fields.summary: Maven2 builder should add --batch-mode to command line
Build artifacts should display the size of the file (if single file)

fields.description:
Bamboo should verify exported zip files, to verify whether the archives are corrupted after each export.

From BSP-418, where the export resulted in corrupt zip archive.
fields.summary: Verify the export zip file is not corrupt, after performing export

fields.description: Please check my alteration of http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/8.7+Enabling+JIRA+integration
fields.summary: Ensure the JIRA integration page is correctly documented.

fields.description:
Bamboo seems to be affected by atlassian-seraph concurrency bug reported in SER-65. I found the following exception in customers logs in support issue, BSP-415
{code}

{code:xml}
<parent>
        <groupId>com.atlassian.pom</groupId>
        <artifactId>atlassian-private-pom</artifactId>
        <version>10</version>
</parent>
{code}
